text:
10 minutes

Solicit what students currently know about bionic arms via the following prompts. Ask students to individually record their answers in their CLUE workspace and then share their answers:

1) What do you know about bionic arms? (e.g., what do they look like, why people might use them, in what ways are they connected to the person’s body, how do they work)

2) If you were tasked to design a bionic arm, what do you think the people who use them would like in terms of appearance and function?

5 minutes

Inform students that throughout this unit we will explore how bionic arms work. Bionic arms are designed for people with congenital or acquired limb differences (e.g., people who lost a limb as a result of an accident). With recent developments in science and engineering, these individuals can now directly control a prosthetic arm as if it was their own biological arm. Consider showing students how hand replacements have changed over time. For additional information on bionic arms click here. Note: any content or links from this guide you find useful can be dragged into your teacher Workspace and published to the class. They will show under the Extensions tab.

10 minutes

Let students know that they will next watch a video clip of a young woman named Tilly who is the first teenager in the U.K. to use bionic arms. Direct students to observe Tilly’s use of the bionic arms and record their observations and questions they have on sticky notes.

Present the "Teen with Bionic Arms Applies Flawless Makeup" video

Once students have finished writing on their sticky notes, collect them and arrange them to create a Driving Question Board in a prominent place of the classroom. We recommend using a piece of poster board with the question “How does Tilly control her bionic arm?” in the middle. This can be added to at any time, so keep the sticky notes around should a student have another thought or question.

10 minutes

Review students’ observations and thinking and bring to mind those that will be most useful for subsequent lessons. Potential student observations and thinking may include:

“There appears to be an adjustable outer case that clamps the bionic arm to Tilly’s upper arm. I saw that someone adjusted the plastic exterior for her during the video clip.”

“There is something that allows the residual muscles in Tilly’s upper arm to move the bionic arm."

“Somehow Tilly’s brain sends the information to the bionic arm."

10 minutes

Ask students to think of potential challenges bionic arm users may encounter (e.g., grabbing small objects, user outgrowing arms, issues with charging, limited mobility in the wrist, waterproofing, heat exposure, cleaning the interface between the bionic arm and the remaining limb, tactile feedback).

Once students brainstorm their ideas individually, ask them to share to the class. Then, have them develop a "Need Statement" in the form of “People using a bionic arm need X in order to do Y.”

Here are some examples of need statements:

“Tilly needs her bionic arms to have flexible fingers in order to apply make-up,” “Someone who uses a bionic arm needs a long battery life so they can use it all day.”

The need statement requires students to think about and understand the underlying problem they are trying to find a solution to. Inform student that right now we are not worried about the “how.” The “how” comes later in the engineering design process.

20 minutes

Direct students to individually, and then collectively (in teams of three to four) create an illustrated and annotated model that shows how Tilly’s bionic arm works.

If students use chart paper or a whiteboard, ask them to take a picture of their model and upload it to their CLUE workspace.

Present the Open Bionics webpage or guide students to it.

tiles.title: A potential initial student illustrated and annotated model

text:
10 minutes

Ask students to add an entry in the "Reflection" tab where they will record their current understanding of how Tilly’s bionic arm works. Encourage students to apply what they observed in the video and reference their model.

The reflection journal is a resource that can be used as a formative assessment of students’ thinking over time. Let students know that this is where they will record their learning and wonderings over the course of the unit.

1 minute

Let students know that throughout the unit will further explore how Tilly’s bionic arm works using a model of a bionic arm that they would be able to control with their own muscle activity.

Extensions

* If time permits (or as a homework assignment), ask students to watch the "Beyond Bionics" video and develop additional questions on bionic arms.

* Ask students to develop questions for a hypothetical interview with Tilly.
